title: House Judiciary Committee Delays Its Vote on Articles of Impeachment
summary: Committee Chairman Nadler calls a recess after daylong debate. WASHINGTON-House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler halted a marathon drafting session on two articles of impeachment against President Trump on Thursday night, calling for the session to resume Friday morning with votes.

title: Ad Giant Dentsu Names Jacki Kelley as CEO of Americas
summary: Former Bloomberg executive takes helm at a challenging time for ad-agency conglomerates. Dentsu Aegis Network , a unit of Japan's Dentsu Inc., named agency and media veteran Jacki Kelley as chief executive of its Americas operations, succeeding Nick Brien, who has been at the helm for almost 2½ years.

title: EU Pledges to Cut Greenhouse-Gas Emissions to Net-Zero by 2050
summary: In a sign of the challenges ahead, Poland refuses to implement the climate plan before June. BRUSSELS-European Union leaders agreed to cut the bloc's greenhouse-gas emissions to net-zero by 2050, coupling efforts to fight climate change with a massive economic transition poised to test EU unity.

title: Letter from the Editor: Kristina O'Neill on the December Issue
summary: The Rock as cover star, the makings of our 'Marriage Story' roundtable and the unerring charm of the Riviera's Hotel du Cap: our monthly letter from the editor. Those who live in the public eye have to manage a tension between their private selves and the face they present to the camera. Pro wrestler turned Hollywood star turned producer-entrepreneur Dwayne Johnson, aka The Rock, seems to walk that line with ease. "He's a genuinely good dude," says Sony Pictures' Tom Rothman. "You absolutely cannot fake that in life." Combining brawn with megawatt charm, he's endeared himself to fans of his blockbuster franchises (including the forthcoming sequel Jumanji: The Next Level) as well as to presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren, a devotee of his HBO series Ballers. His ability to connect with seemingly unforced authenticity may explain his massive Instagram following-at last count, 162 million strong.

title: Contributors to the December 2019 Issue of WSJ. Magazine
summary: Photographer Maciek Kobielski, writer Lakin Starling and other contributors to WSJ.'s December issue. For this issue's roundtable with Marriage Story director Noah Baumbach and stars Adam Driver, Laura Dern and Scarlett Johansson, writer Alex Bhattacharji and photographer Maciek Kobielski sought to capture the foursome's personalities as vividly as the movie reveals its characters. "The film is such an incredibly intimate portrait of a marriage," says Bhattacharji. "I was left wondering how well they had to know each other in order to achieve that ease." Kobielski found his task a challenge, given that he had only 45 minutes to shoot them individually and as a group. "Luckily, when you have a great director and three awesome actors in front of you, the gods are on your side," he says. Bhattacharji compared the discussion to a family dinner. "The energy sort of mirrored the film: They were thoughtful and spoke with deep emotion," he says, "punctuated with genuine humor and some good-natured ribbing."

title: Top Lawmakers Say Bipartisan Spending Deal Reached
summary: Negotiators announce the accord as government funding is slated to run out after Dec. 20. WASHINGTON-Top Democratic and Republican lawmakers said they reached a tentative agreement on federal government spending, giving Congress and the White House about a week to approve the particulars before funding runs out after Dec. 20.

title: Mick Mulvaney on Impeachment, a China Trade Deal and the Budget Deficit
summary: The acting White House chief of staff also talks about the economic impact of the tax cuts and priorities for a second term. Acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, in an appearance at The Wall Street Journal's annual CEO Council meeting on Tuesday, was noncommittal when asked whether he and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo would testify in a Senate impeachment hearing.

title: Warren Chides 2020 Rivals as She Lays Out Economic Vision
summary: Senator doesn't name other candidates but appears to take swipes at Biden, Buttigieg. Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren drew a sharper contrast with her 2020 rivals, offering thinly veiled swipes at Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg in an address that previewed how she would challenge President Trump's economic policies in a general election.

title: Trump Agrees to Limited Trade Deal With China
summary: Plan would prevent new tariffs planned for Sunday and roll back some existing tariff rates. President Trump has agreed to a limited trade agreement with Beijing that will roll back existing tariff rates on Chinese goods and cancel new levies set to take effect Sunday as part of a deal to boost Chinese purchases of U.S. farm goods and obtain other concessions, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Boeing's MAX Fixes Not Likely to Get FAA Approval Until February
summary: FAA says the agency and the company 'must take the time to get this process right'. The global grounding of Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX is bound to stretch to nearly a year as U.S. regulators chided the plane maker for its slow delivery of information and warned it against setting unrealistic expectations for the jetliner's return to service.

summary: Warren Buffett protegé Tracy Britt Cool is on the board. EverArc Holdings Ltd., a British Virgin Islands-based acquisition vehicle, said it raised $340 million in an initial offering in London.

title: A Nuclear Milestone for Climate
summary: Federal go-ahead for Florida reactors could start a chain reaction.. You probably haven't heard about a recent regulatory decision that will reduce carbon emissions because it doesn't follow the green template of controlling private industry and suppressing economic growth.

title: Warren's Economic Illusions
summary: A new analysis says her wealth tax would fall short-by $1.5 trillion.. Elizabeth Warren has been justly criticized for the magical math in her Medicare for All proposal. That health plan would cost perhaps $34 trillion, according to outside estimates. But Ms. Warren says the true figure is only-alakazam!-$20.5 trillion.

title: Oracle Won't Return to Dual-CEO Structure
summary: Company reports increase in profit though revenue falls short of Wall Street expectations. Oracle Corp. said it won't replace its late co-CEO, Mark Hurd, leaving Safra Catz as the sole top executive leading the software giant after years of operating with an unusual, two-chief structure.

summary: In Iowa, candidates and voters show little interest in impeachment, much in victory next November.. Cedar Rapids, Iowa

title: The FBI's Fusion Fiasco
summary: Christopher Steele has little credibility left after the inspector general's report.. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has had its worst week in modern history. The Justice Department's inspector general found that the bureau had deceived a federal court and abused Americans' civil liberties. It was equally humiliating for the crew that gulled the FBI into its excesses: Fusion GPS, Christopher Steele and their media acolytes.

title: A Rabbi Walks Into a Presbyterian Church
summary: I serve a synagogue but also teach, preach and counsel a local Christian community.. I am a full-time pulpit rabbi serving a Conservative synagogue in Santa Monica, Calif. This year I also am periodically teaching, counseling and preaching to Christians as a pastoral associate at Brentwood Presbyterian Church. This may seem like a strange arrangement, but it has been fruitful for both congregations. Rather than trying to convert each other, we're finding ways to enrich our own faiths together.

title: How to Pay the Wealth Tax: Sell Everything
summary: Investors could pay twice as much in capital gains just to raise the funds for Ms. Warren's levy.. Elizabeth Warren's proposed wealth tax-an annual levy on the total value of one's assets, not income-has drawn a lot of attention. The senator's claim that her proposal would cost "ultramillionaires" only an annual 2% and billionaires an annual 6% wildly understates the truth. Wealthy people don't maintain bank accounts with millions or billions of dollars of liquid cash; they invest their assets. Those hit with the wealth tax would have to sell assets each year to pay it, subjecting them to income tax as well. The actual cost would often be several times greater than 2% or 6%.

title: Seattle's Wage Mandate Kills Restaurants
summary: The legal minimum is going to $16.39 an hour, while my pay drops to zero.. Seattle

title: 'Disney's Land' Review: A Day in the Park With Walt
summary: Researchers told Disney that his amusement park would fail if it didn't have a Ferris wheel and a roller coaster. He had something else in mind.. As understatements go, this one's a doozy. Its source was Roy Disney, the less heralded, less handsome and-as gleaned from Richard Snow's richly engaging "Disney's Land"-less headstrong brother of Walt Disney. Since 1923, Roy had been the business brains of the Disney company was no stranger to his kid brother's "screwy ideas." But when he was informed after the war that his sibling had been, over his objections, slyly seeking funds to develop his own amusement park, Roy's response was: "Junior's got his hand in the cookie jar again."

title: Modi Courts Chaos by Snubbing Persecuted Muslims
summary: A new citizenship law gives 'special consideration' to most every other religious minority-and Hindus.. title: Government Bond Yields Surge After Trump Declares Progress on Trade

summary: Airline says it would share with employees $125 million of the proceeds from its agreement. Southwest Airlines Co. and Boeing Co. said they struck a deal to compensate the airline for some of the damage from the nine-month grounding of the 737 MAX jetliner.

summary: Albertsons, Walmart and other chains try to get closer to customers to fill online orders faster. Food retailers are making big bets on small warehouses to bulk up their growing delivery businesses, as supermarkets try different approaches to get groceries to customers more efficiently.

summary: Vendors who kept Sears stocked during bankruptcy will get paid about 33 cents on the dollar for administrative claims. Vendors who kept the shelves stocked for last year's holidays during Sears Holding Corp. 's bankruptcy will finally get paid.

summary: Shows like 'Das Boot,' 'Our Boys' and 'The Spy' gave this year's most distinguished programming a decidedly international flavor.. The best shows of 2019 were set around the globe and shared a common theme-the drama of war and the pursuit of justice. Subtitles abounded.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Thursday that Lorie Logan, a longtime executive at the bank, will become the manager of the central bank's asset portfolio, while Daleep Singh, an economist who previously served at the Treasury Department, will run the bank's markets group.

summary: Trump administration, facing lobbying push by Turkey, had pushed Congress not to approve measure. WASHINGTON-The Senate approved a resolution recognizing the Armenian genocide, delivering a rebuke to Turkey despite White House resistance to the measure.

summary: Supreme Court to review the long-running dispute over management to Flint and Chattahoochee rivers. A federal judge sided with Georgia over Florida in a long-running case over the right to draw water from a river basin shared between the two increasingly parched states.

summary: Gov. Poloz gave no indication that a near-term interest rate cut is in the offing. TORONTO-Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz reiterated his comfort with rate policy and the state of the country's economy on Thursday, suggesting he won't be dissuaded by a single month of disappointing jobs data.

title: Liberty Media Seeks to Increase Stake in iHeartMedia
summary: Deal would put nation's largest radio broadcaster under same umbrella as concert promoter and satellite-radio giant SiriusXM. An affiliate of John Malone's Liberty Media Corp. is seeking Justice Department permission to buy a larger piece of iHeartMedia Inc., according to people familiar with the matter, a deal that would put the nation's largest radio broadcaster under the same corporate umbrella as the leading concert promoter and satellite-radio giant SiriusXM.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Thursday it is again increasing the scope of liquidity operations it is willing to offer financial markets to ensure money-market rates remain relatively calm over an uncertain year-end.

The National Labor Relations Board instructed a federal judge to approve a settlement in a case pertaining to McDonald's Corp.'s status as a joint employer, helping shield the company from liability from the employment practices of its hundreds of U.S. franchisees.

summary: U.S. negotiators offer to cut existing tariff rates by up to 50% on $360 billion of Chinese imports. Stocks climbed Thursday after President Trump said on Twitter that the U.S. and China are nearing a trade deal.

title: Bloomberg in 'Outstanding Health,' Says Doctor
summary: Former mayor had surgery for blocked artery in 2000, is treated for arthritis and heartburn. Billionaire Michael Bloomberg's presidential campaign released a letter Thursday from his longtime doctor that describes the 77-year-old as being in "outstanding health."

title: 'A Hidden Life' Review: Mournful, Memorable and Emotionally Exhilarating
summary: Terrence Malick turns his deeply insightful eye to Franz Jägerstätter, an Austrian who resisted pledging loyalty to Hitler and paid the price..

title: 'Richard Jewell': Terror, Error, Redemption
summary: Director Clint Eastwood's take on the ordeal of the security guard caught up in the Atlanta Olympics bombing is an impressive enterprise, despite one misstep.. If they gave an award for Film With the Unlikeliest Hero, "Richard Jewell" would win hands down. A security guard at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta, Jewell was quickly lionized for saving countless lives by finding a terrorist's bomb before it detonated, then just as quickly vilified as the suspected bomber. The film, directed zestfully by Clint Eastwood from a screenplay that Billy Ray adapted from a magazine article by Marie Brenner, is more than unlikely. It's an affecting portrait of a serious, if deeply eccentric, person who was usually taken for a clown, as well as an unsparing depiction of twin juggernauts that nearly wrecked his life: a national media mob, running with an irresponsible story, and the FBI, its investigation riddled with improprieties. The production comes with an asterisk concerning its own allegiance to the facts of the media madness. More about that controversy later, except to say the material in dispute is peripheral and unaccountably dumb, since it adds nothing to an otherwise impressive enterprise.

title: 'Uncut Gems': The Fateful Lure of Chaos
summary: Adam Sandler's jewel salesman is a palpable knot of anxiety in this darkly captivating film.. Can a movie that generates steady-state anxiety also function as entertainment? Yes it can, and Adam Sandler is here to prove it in "Uncut Gems," a hard-edged and hard-charging phenomenon directed by Benny Safdie and Josh Safdie from a screenplay the brothers wrote with Ronald Bronstein. Mr. Sandler is flat-out sensational as Howard Ratner, a gem dealer in Manhattan's diamond district. Anxiety is what drives Howard, fuels him, tells him he's alive. He revises his life from minute to minute, racing this way, chasing that way, making phone calls, placing long-odds bets. He appears to be multitasking but there's only one task, staying two steps ahead of the chaos and danger he created for himself just a moment before. Quiet desperation isn't for him. Howard likes his loud, violent and vulgar. He isn't lovable, or even likable, but as borderline lunatics go he's a brilliant spectacle.

title: 'Seberg': You Never Know Who's Watching
summary: Kristen Stewart plays Jean Seberg, the star of Jean-Luc Godard films who was surveilled by the FBI..

summary: Shares that are sensitive to developments on U.S.-China trade talks outperforming S&P 500. Shares of companies sensitive to U.S.-China trade policy are rallying on hopes that the two countries may be nearing an agreement.

title: Searchers Find Wreckage of Antarctica-Bound Chilean Plane
summary: Military leader says it is 'practically impossible' that any of the 38 people aboard survived. Wreckage and human remains from a Chilean military aircraft that disappeared on a flight to Antarctica with 38 people aboard have been discovered in the turbulent waters off South America's southern tip, Chile's government said Thursday.

title: Kentucky's New Governor Restores Voting Rights to Nonviolent Felons
summary: Democrat Andy Beshear takes early action, as promised from campaign trail. Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear signed an executive order Thursday restoring voting rights to more than 140,000 people with nonviolent felony convictions, one of his earliest acts after being sworn into office.

title: Warren Wealth Tax Would Raise Nearly 30% Less Than Projected, Study Finds
summary: Democratic candidate's plan would generate $1.1 trillion less than estimated; campaign says tougher enforcement can close gap. title: The World's Cash Is Disappearing. Bankers Aren't Sure Where It Went.
summary: Check your pockets. Society is increasingly going cashless, but banknotes are more in demand. Bankers search for clues.. Some Australians are burying it. The Swiss might be hiding it. The Germans are probably hoarding.

title: George Laurer, Defying Instructions, Created Universal Bar Code
summary: Unassuming IBM engineer followed his own logic-and was amazed at how well it worked. If he had followed instructions from his boss, George Laurer might never have succeeded in designing the Universal Product Code.

title: 'Wisting' Review: A Detective at Work
summary: A Norwegian homicide detective-paired with an FBI agent-on the hunt for a serial killer is a singular presence in this show on Sundance Now.. This seamlessly woven thriller centers on the life and work of homicide detective William Wisting, a hero devoid of any trace of psychological darkness, internal demons, or singular passions of any kind-he's not devoted to the opera either-characteristic of so many fictional detectives. For this, and all other aspects of Wisting's heroically stolid presence (a stellar performance by Sven Nordin), there is every reason to be thankful as the 10 episodes of this superbly layered drama (begins Wednesday, Sundance Now) roll on. ("Wisting" is based on the Norwegian crime novels "The Cave Man" and "The Hunting Dogs" by Jørn Lier Horst and was written and created by Trygve Allister Diesen and Kathrine Valen Zeiner.)

title: Cheap vs. Pricey Cashmere: Here's the Real Difference
summary: Why do similar-looking basic crewneck sweaters run the gamut from $75 to over $1,000? The determining factors range from provenance of the wool to design details to the 'kissability test'. LIGHT AND SOFT, cashmere is sometimes called the "diamond fiber." Culled from the bellies of certain well-dressed goats, the fine hairs are naturally scarce and were traditionally accordingly priced. But roughly 20 years ago, decades after your grandfather passed on his one precious Pringle of Scotland sweater to your father, the prized fiber went mass-market. Its price dipped during the Asian financial crisis, whetting demand and triggering expansions by producers in China and Mongolia and timesaving fabrication shortcuts. What was once a fancy-schmancy item became a bargain at Costco . Today, prices for cashmere crew necks range from $75 for direct-to-consumer versions from Naadam to $1,985 for a "baby cashmere" piece from Italian luxury brand Loro Piana. But is there an appreciable difference?

title: One of the Biggest Homes in the Hollywood Hills Sells for $35.5 Million
summary: The property built by real-estate developer Jeff Thomas is more than 20,000 square feet and includes a 175-foot outdoor pool with a waterfall.

title: Judges Spar Over Emoluments Suit Against Trump
summary: The president is seeking the lawsuit's dismissal. RICHMOND, Va.-Federal appeals court judges here sparred over President Trump's bid to obtain dismissal of a lawsuit alleging he is violating the Constitution because his businesses are profiting from his presidency.

title: Cooler Forecasts Buoy Natural Gas Prices, Threaten a Big Short
summary: Bets that prices will keep falling are running into dropping temperatures in the Eastern U.S.. Forecasts for cooler weather to close out the month buoyed natural gas prices on Thursday, halting a slide that has trimmed roughly 20% off the heating fuel since early November.

title: Investigators See Jersey City Shooting as Potential Act of Domestic Terror
summary: 'The evidence points towards acts of hate,' says New Jersey's attorney general. summary: The change to baseball's drug policy includes removing marijuana from list of drugs of abuse. SAN DIEGO-All major-league players will face mandatory testing for opioids starting next spring training, a significant change to baseball's drug policy, under a new agreement announced Thursday by Major League Baseball and its players union.

title: Markets Welcome Christine Lagarde's First ECB Policy Meeting
summary: Bank stocks rally, interest rates tick higher after Lagarde expresses dissatisfaction over efforts to ignite inflation. Bank stocks and government bonds reacted positively to Christine Lagarde's first policy decision as President of the European Central Bank, taking their cue from her slightly more optimistic comments about growth in the eurozone.

title: House Passes Bill to Reduce Drug Prices
summary: Pelosi-backed measure gives Democrats talking point for 2020 election; GOP says it undercuts bipartisan effort in Senate. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives passed far-reaching legislation to lower drug prices, bolstering Democrats' health-care message in the 2020 election campaign, although the bill has almost no chance to be taken up by the Republican-controlled Senate.

title: Free College Makes Sense for Those Qualified
summary: Free education, should we ever be in position truly to offer it, in no way constrains an institution's need to ensure that students qualify for admission.. In "'Free College for All' Is an Experiment That Has Already Failed" (op-ed, Dec. 7), Prof. Jackson Toby conflates the idea of public higher education being accessible to those who qualify academically and the idea that qualifications should be cast aside altogether. Free education, should we ever be in position truly to offer it, in no way constrains an institution's need to ensure that students qualify for admission.

title: You Don't Build Kids' Characters With Lies
summary: With the best of intentions, my own parents, who were lapsed Catholics, lied to me exactly as advised by Ms. Komisar.. As a human being and as a psychiatrist, I am appalled by Erica Komisar's "Don't Believe in God? Lie to Your Children" (Houses of Worship, Dec. 6). Lying to children is harmful. Your children may not always figure out the exact truth behind your lies, but they will almost always sense that something isn't right. With the best of intentions, my own parents, who were lapsed Catholics, lied to me exactly as advised by Ms. Komisar. Outcome: I rejected religion as fishy as early as age 8 but felt compelled to keep my atheism a secret for years. I got so good at telling my Sunday school teachers what they wanted to hear that a priest once showed up at my house to tell my father that I had a vocation. A tendency to mistrust authority figures persisted for decades and interfered with my ability to bond with potential mentors at school and work.

title: Forced Fire Insurance Is a Terrible, Destructive Idea
summary: When insurers can't price the risk, they are understandably reluctant to write policies. Compelling them to do so, particularly at "affordable" prices, sends the signal that maybe the risk isn't so great.. Although the wildfire situation in California is tragic, misguided efforts to help homeowners by compelling insurers to write policies isn't the solution ("California Restricts Home Insurers," U.S. News, Dec. 6). Insurance rates should reflect the level of risk, which is obviously quite high in California. When insurers can't price the risk, they are understandably reluctant to write policies. Compelling them to do so, particularly at "affordable" prices, sends the signal that maybe the risk isn't so great. This is really a driving factor in what has now become a perpetual disaster. We only have to look at the National Flood Insurance Program to see where this policy leads. Instead of helping vulnerable homeowners recover from flooding as envisioned, it has enticed millions of people to move to vulnerable coastal locations because the cost of those decisions is now borne by everyone, regardless of where they choose to live. Following a similar path with wildfires is both imprudent and immoral.

title: Progressive Finance Pooling
summary: Democrat presidential candidate rivals stand unified in their beliefs of income redistribution and economic equality for all Americans.. Regarding your editorial "Kamala Harris Returns to the Senate" (Dec. 4): Sen. Kamala Harris and her (former) Democratic presidential candidate rivals stand unified in their support of income redistribution and economic equality for all Americans. It seems fair that they adapt this ideology to campaign funding by agreeing to pool all contributions raised by their individual efforts and share them equally.

title: The CIA's Former Chief of Disguise Drops Her Mask
summary: Jonna Mendez served 27 years undercover, crafting wigs, prosthetic noses, false teeth and masks that could be peeled off like Tom Cruise's in 'Mission: Impossible'. One morning during the presidency of George H.W. Bush, Jonna Mendez, then the CIA's chief of disguise, entered the White House wearing a mask. She had originally disguised herself as an African-American man but decided that mask wouldn't work, not least because her voice would give her away. Instead, she borrowed the face of a female colleague. "It was a little nerve-racking," she recalls. "I hadn't really worn it anywhere." She sat outside the Oval Office, chewing her pencil through the mask, until the president was ready for his morning intelligence briefing.

title: Anderson Cooper and Padma Lakshmi on Gracefulness
summary: WSJ. Magazine asks six luminaries to weigh in on a single topic. This month: Grace. Anderson Cooper, Max Richter, Padma Lakshmi and more respond. "As a reporter, my greatest desire is to be a decent and good human being, to be fair and to have the questions I ask be truthful. We live in an age when people puff themselves up and want to have the most followers on Instagram and to show themselves having this glamorous, fun, exciting life. That seems to me sort of the opposite of grace. There's something about the quiet fortitude of the people I most like to do stories about, whether it's in Mississippi after Hurricane Katrina or Haiti after the earthquake. For my dad, who grew up in a poor family in Mississippi, the song 'Amazing Grace' was always incredibly important, and he used to cry every time he heard it. ' 'Twas grace that taught my heart to fear and grace my fears relieved.' I don't think that many people embrace that idea-that they want their heart to fear yet then, through grace, have their fears relieved."

title: A Day in the Life of Away Luggage Co-Founder Jen Rubio
summary: The company's chief brand officer isn't stopping at luggage-she's got plans for the future of travel and beyond. Every morning at 6 a.m., Jen Rubio, 32, co-founder and chief brand officer of travel gear startup Away, wakes to the melodic alarm sounds of sleep app Pzizz and works out on her Peloton bike. "I need a solid hour of alone time to prepare for what's ahead of me that day," she says. Rubio, who calls both San Francisco and New York home, spends her days at product-review sessions, photo shoots and new-hire happy hours. She pings between Away's recently opened headquarters in New York's SoHo and its offices in London, which together house the more than 300 full-time employees of the nearly five-year-old company, valued at $1.4 billion as of May.

title: The New 'Little Women' Will Make You Want to Wear 1860s Fashion
summary: The costumes in the latest film adaptation of the beloved novel, written and directed by Greta Gerwig, are already surprisingly in sync with the current trend for high necklines and calico. A DELIGHTFUL SCENE in the new adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's "Little Women" depicts the four March sisters cavorting on a New England beach dressed in their summer finery: floral calico fabrics, pie-crust collars and peplums. This quartet of billowing Civil War-era frocks was costume designer Jacqueline Durran's favorite moment in the film (coming Dec. 25), written and directed by Greta Gerwig. "What I did was to create historically accurate pieces but then let them be worn in a way that the girls were comfortable with," explained Ms. Durran. That "looseness in approach" made the outfits modern, she added, though she also particularly loved the suite of beach costumes in part because of their period-appropriateness.
